Consider the function used as priority key in A* algorithm.

Admissible

  • Guarantees optimality if before adding a node to fringe,
    • Check if is traversed.
      • If so, check if current path is better than the one traversed
        • If so, add to fringe
    • Check if is in fringe.
      • If so, check if current path is better than the one in fringe
        • If so, add to fringe
    • Add to fringe

  • Proof:

    Algorithm terminates when the vertex with minimum is the destination, .

    If the algorithm terminates with admissible heuristic but the optimal path hasnâ€™t been found, we must have , for some on the output path, .

    But . Then . Contradiction with the definition of admissibility. QED.

  • The above algorithm resembles tree search.

Consistent

  • Implies non-decreasing on every path.

  • Guarantees optimality by ensuring, whenever a node is popped out of the fringe, it is from the shortest path to it.

  • Thus, new node can be ignored if it was traversed.
    • Cannot ignore if it is in the fringe and to be traversed.
    • In the above case, replace the one in the fringe if current path is better. i.e. lower .
  • The above algorithm is graph search.
